steps.title: How DNS Resolution Works.
You open a web browser on your computer.
You type a website address like example.com into the browser.
But computers don't understand domain names. They need IP addresses - numbers like 93.184.216.34.
DNS (Domain Name System) translates domain names to IP addresses. It's like a phonebook for the Internet.
Your computer sends the domain name to a DNS Resolver. This is usually provided by your Internet Service Provider (ISP).
The DNS Resolver doesn't know every website. It needs to ask other servers.
First, it asks a Root Server. There are 13 root server clusters worldwide that know where to find everything.
The Root Server doesn't know the exact IP. But it knows who handles .com domains.
The Root Server directs the resolver to a TLD (Top-Level Domain) Server that handles .com addresses.
The .com TLD Server knows which server is authoritative for example.com.
The TLD Server points to the Authoritative Name Server for example.com.
The Authoritative Server has the actual DNS records for example.com.
It returns the IP address: 93.184.216.34
The IP address travels back through the DNS Resolver to your browser.
Now your browser knows the IP address of example.com.
Your browser can now connect directly to the web server at that IP address.
The web server sends back the website content (HTML, images, etc.).
This whole DNS lookup process happens in milliseconds!
To speed things up, DNS Resolvers cache (remember) IP addresses for a while.
Next time you visit example.com, the resolver can skip asking all those servers.
That's DNS - the Internet's phonebook that translates names to numbers!
